oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Hallmarks of Country Music - Jim Ed Brown
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview of Jim Ed Brown (musician). The interview is hosted by Rick Phillips (army sergeant/ radio host) for the Hallmarks of Country Music segment. The tape was recorded on an unidentified date.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Jim Ed Brown; Rick Phillips
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Muffled unidentified tune and voice -- (00:53) Promotion for Hallmarks of Country Music featuring Jim Ed Brown-- (01:26) Hallmarks tune [featuring Rick Phillips introduction voiceover] ([Unidentified]) -- (02:00) Three Bells (The Browns) -- (04:48) Rick Phillips introduces Brown to reflect on his time working with the Browns, and Phillips inquires about "Three Bells" -- (09:05) Looking Back to See (The Browns) -- (10:05) Department of Army radio spot hosted by Phillips -- (10:30) Scarlet Ribbons (The Browns) -- (13:03) National Institutes of Health Computer Center commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (14:05) The Old Lamp-lighter (The Browns) -- (16:23) Phillips invites Brown to reflect on "The Old Lamp-Lighter" and "Pop a Top" -- (20:36) Pop a Top (Jim Ed Brown) -- (22:50) Phillips performs a weather-proofing radio spot -- (23:17) Skeeter Davis performs an Army Reserve commercial spot -- (24:21) Unbelievable Love (Jim Ed Brown) -- (27:00) Red Cross commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (27:30) Broad Minded Man (Jim Ed Brown) -- (29:53) Davis compares a story about "Broad Minded Man" to his family experience -- (33:20) Sometime Sunshine (Jim Ed Brown) -- (35:50) Army and Air Force exchanges radio spot hosted by Phillips -- (36:20) Morning (The Brown) -- (39:20) It's That Time of Night (Jim Ed Brown) -- (42:44) Phillips and Brown reflect on Bill Graham's exponential song-writing, and Phillips inquires about Brown's appreciation of women -- (47:30) Fire prevention radio spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (48:40) Get Up, I Think I Love You (Jim Ed Brown) -- (50:56) Phillips inquires as to Brown's idea of the state of country music, and both say their goodbyes -- (54:38) Hallmarks tune [featuring Rick Phillips outro voiceover] ([Unidentified])
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Brown, Jim Ed; Brown, Jim Ed, 1934-2015; Phillips, Rick;
